11x8.5"
Ephemera Booklet (sample characters)

62078.name: Challenge (Issue 67)
62078.description:
From the credits page:

Challenge, the magazine of science-fiction gaming, is published monthly.

About the Cover: This month, artist Tim Conrad imparts to us the necessity of being well-protected when dealing with down-sized trolls in the Shadowrun universe.

62079.name: Challenge (Issue 69)
rpgissuearticle: Special Insert! When Empires Fall, part II
62079.description:
From the credits page:

Challenge, the magazine of science-fiction gaming, is published bimonthly.

About the Cover: Ray Van Tilburg shows us MS Vigilante conducting flight ops off gas giant Salem (Daaliisa/2725 Diaspora) in 1130, shortly before being struck down by the AI Virus. Note Kestrel-type fighter painted in deceptive pirate markings.

62080.name: Day of the Saru - Part 1
62080.description:
From the Publisher:

An Official Living Jungle Campaign Adventure For Heroes Of All Levels

“Visions. Dreams. Vague yearnings. Distant drums. A call to adventure has come at last. Think you know all there is to know of Malatra? Foolish children. The dark jungle holds many secrets. Some beautiful. Some terrible. All wondrous. If you would know more, now is the time to answer the call.”

The adventure begins with the heroes being drawn to the Jungle Giants village of Hafoka. This village is located in the south west, north of Kumbo Swamp and west of the Dreaming River. It is largely an unexplored territory, though Pathfinders and Scouts have reported animals, plants and insects of gigantic proportion. It is whispered that the Allmuseri, the evil society of necromantic shamans live here, as well as the last of the cannibalistic tribes.

62082.name: Block by Bloody Block
62082.description:
Back Cover:

You can look out over the city and see what you want to see. Maybe you see the bright lights, and it gives you hope. Maybe you see the tall buildings casting their powerful shadows, and it makes you feel small. But high up, it’s not that you can’t see the forest for the trees—it’s that you can’t see the trees for the forest.

Best way to see what’s really going on? Turn away from the bright lights, big city, and sit down at this card table right here and roll out a map. Take this box-cutter, and just start hacking it up. Slice-slice. The docks go to the bloodsuckers, the banks, too. The projects, we don’t know who has them because we can’t get close. The park falls to the beasts, and the highways to the jackals. Slice-slice. You cut the place to ribbons, then soak it in blood, because that’s how they got what they got—by soaking the city in blood, theirs and everybody else’s.

And this right here? This tiny piece, this shitty little nowhere piece that’s half the size of a postage stamp? That’s your cut. That’s your part of this god-forsaken city. You content with that? You satisfied leaving the fatty cuts and the sweet meats for the monsters to fight over? Maybe you are. But I’m not. So gear up, because it’s liberation time.

— LCpl Erwin Emerson (ret.), leader of the Crusaders of Night cell

BlockThis book includes:

Systems to run a Hunter: The Vigil chronicle on a larger scale, reclaiming parts of your city from various supernatural factions
Eight urban territories, complete with story seeds and Storyteller characters, ready to be dropped into an existing chronicle or modified to your troupe’s tastes
Storytelling advice on how to create your own territories, as well as running a Block by Bloody Block chronicle

62083.name: Game News (Issue 11 - Jan 1986)
62083.description:
User Summary:

Table of Contents...

Special Features

A Look at William Carman by Anne F. Jaffe




Cartoon Features

Halbritter's Arms Through the Ages by Kurt Halbritter
Bad Moves by Dan Steffan




Role-Games

So How's the Weather by Lee Enderlin
Mimnon "Hardheart" [Rolemaster III] by Mike Dawson
Reviews
Miniatures




War Games

Sometimes Nobody Loves You [Hammer's Slammers] by William Fawcett
Finetuning Antietam [Rules change's for SPI/TSR's Gleam of Bayonets] by Dale L. Kemper
The Indirect Approach by Jon Southard
Research Shelf by David Parham and T.P. Schweider
Reviews
Miniatures




General Adult Games

What Can You Expect [Marketing your game] by Steve Peek
Reviews

62084.name: Bad Night at Blackmoon Farm
62084.description:
From the Introduction:
This is the sad and simple fact: we’re a society of needy people. We’re so desperate to belong. We’ll do anything to make friends. To look good. To find some kind of companionship and affirmation, or some sense of spiritual satisfaction, real or false. Is it any wonder that in this World of Darkness cults spring up again and again, growing swiftly and without warning like a bad patch of choking weeds?

Thing is, though, very rarely does a cult start off as exactly that. No, they usually begin with more auspicious and beneficent ideals. A self-help group aims to better its members or, at the worst, its leader hopes to milk some suckers out of a couple bucks. But over time, it shifts. Each member relies a little too much on the group dynamic; they grow co-dependent, and instead of diminishing their desperation, it only blooms anew. It leaves a spiritual hole into which something bad may crawl. They’ll fill the chasm with whatever they can: a demon’s seductive whispers, a drink from a vampire’s wrist, an infectious lunacy whose whispers will not—cannot—be refused. It may take a few months. It may take a dozen years. But over time, the cult mentality takes over. And sometimes, hunters must step in.

But what happens when it’s hunters that grow to become the cultists? What happens when a cell or compact of hunters becomes mired in that cult mentality, opening themselves up to the callous manipulations of a monster?

Welcome to a Bad Night at Blackmoon Farm.

62085.name: Pacific Coast Trail
62085.description:
The mode of travel in the game, hiking, introduces players to the situations and problems that are usually encountered while traveling from one location to another. The game also familiarizes the players with the opportunities to visit different national ecological gifts, canyons, parks and mountains along their travel route.

Contents:

1 - six sided die
12 - player pieces
4 sets of red regional cards (20 cards each)
4 sets of green regional cards (20 cards each)
100 - thin sheet Inventory Cards (can be copied to fill future use)

62086.name: Pathways To Leadership
62086.description:
Leadership is a set of skills that anyone can learn to use effectively. Some people are natural leaders, while others craft and hone their leadership skills. Regardless of leadership ability, this game will provide the opportunity to define specific leadership traits within six domains, provide the opportunity to interact and practice these traits with peers, and test knowledge of leadership trivia.

The goal of the game is to complete an individual path to leadership. The path for each player is unique (as it is in life) and has many obstacles to overcome to reach the finish line. Each player is challenged to make positive leadership decisions, recognize leadership traits and identify prominent leaders from many different cultures . Each play engages at least two of the players and some involve all four. The game ends when all players have completed their individual paths to leadership. Scores are tallied and used to determined leadership strengths and weaknesses for each player.

Contents:
* Board Player pieces
* Trait cards
* Scenario cards
* Leader cards
* Time piece (sand glass)
* Four sided die
* Score card
* Observation cards
* Leadership domains and trait description cards
* Leader list cards

62087.name: Zif
62087.description:
From the publisher:

It came from the deep dark depths of the sea. It is eons old; it saw the dinosaurs evolve and vanish. It survived countless cataclysms. It features a slimy squid-like parasitic brain inside an amorphous armored body. Run! Run for your life! No, wait! It is just the friendly zif. Join this benevolent snail-like PC race on a quest for knowledge and fortune. Ever wanted to play something a little different? That is the whole point of Alluria Publishing’s Remarkable Races. We offer something new, with original color art (Dean Specer—featured in the Entobians—is the artist for the Zif), and new and improved rules guidelines to bring you the best possible product.
Remarkable Races: The Zif is one 4th Edition D&D race, with full statistics and extras, ready to play right out of the box.

62088.name: Taddol
62088.description:
From the publisher:

Two heads are better than one! The Taddol is bound to be the talk of the table as it offers the first-ever two-headed player option. Have a friend that you work well with? Want to play two PCs but the game master doesn’t want to deal with an extra mini on the table? Or may you are a DM and you want to add an NPC that a particular player can’t get rid of! Taddols are a quirky blend of ettin (two-headed giants; mean, slobbering, stupid) and eladrin (high elves; sophisticated, beautiful, ingenious). They are strong, smart, and tall. Masterfully put together in revised Alluria style; all original art by Vasilis Zikos, several layers of editing and rules checking, and play tested till it meets the approval of the fussiest gamers. This is one 4th Edition D&D race, with full statistics and extras, ready to play right out of the box.

62089.name: Relluk
62089.description:
From the publisher:

Move over warforged, a new living construct is coming into your game! Well, by new we mean old…very, very old. The relluks were made to be stony protectors for a remote island nation several thousand years ago. Unfortunately, they failed…the nation was obliterated before the Relluks could even be activated. They stood in droves for millennia waiting to spring to life. The time is now! Rediscover an ancient technology in these odd beings with menacing tribal faces, crystal souls, and bodies crafted from volcanic rock. Will they avenge their ancestors? What is the source of their power? What do they do now? You can answer all these questions and more when you step out of the pages of Remarkable Races: The Relluk. colorful and original illustrations await with expertly designed rules.

Add some new life to your 4th edition D&D game!

62090.name: Mahrog
62090.description:
From the publisher:

The mahrog: a product of simpler times when man and beast were one. I’m talking cavemen; nasty, brutish and short! The mahrogs may be marching into your game, dragging clubs, flinging spears, and just generally being crude.Mothered by an overprotective nature goddess, the mahrogs shun modern conveniences like metal armor and fancy swords in favor of wood, bone, and stone. Best of all, it works well for them due to some divine intervention on the part of their goddess protector. So if you ever pined for simpler times, it doesn’t get any more primitive than this! Of course, the mahrogs follow the same great format as the other races with colorful original art, complete rules and extras, and are ready to play immediately. Made for the 4th Edition D&D game.

62091.name: Anumus
62091.description:
From the publisher:

Eleven distinct races in one! Man’s best friend just got an upgrade. Meet the Anumi; pets who have undergone a radical transformation into humanoid versions of their former selves. More than just anthropomorphic animals; they have an ancient secret that once made them direct representatives of the gods themselves. With this catch-all bestial race, personify your favorite animal and lead him into combat against evil! Dogs, wolves, cats, tigers, horses, pigs, rats, birds, and more are all an option. In true revised Allurian style; all original art by Eugene Jaworski, full rules overhaul, and strenuous play testing. This is one 4th Edition D&D race, with full statistics and extras, ready to play right out of the box.

62092.name: Mogogol
62092.description:
From the publisher:

For eons the amphibious frog people common to the dismal swamps of the realm were known for malicious cruelty, greed, and cowardice-- acts that earned them the nickname bog-bullies. It seemed entirely unlikely that any good could come from these stupid and ugly muck dwellers, but something strange happened only two centuries ago that would dawn a new race of impeccable good. A curse, some say it was. An untherwise unremarkable family of bog-bullies, known as the Mogogols could do no harm. Driven by an insane desire to do good deeds, and lead by other manic tendencies, this race left the dismal swamps and embarked on a remarkable journey. When hard times befell other other frog-like races, the Mogogols were there to lend a flipper. Nearly two-hundred years later, the mogogols emerged as a unique race in their own right. Grab your sword and hop into action with this new PC race brought to you by Alluria Publishing. Ever wanted to play a swashbuckling frog, an amphibious acrobat, or a toadly priest? Then perhaps mogogol is the race for you!
Published under the Fourth Edition GSL. Full racial statistics for a new PC race, feats, monster blocks, and much much more! Colorfully illustrated.

62093.name: Obitu
62093.description:
From the publisher:

From the darkest corner, Lord Varquil the Lich plotted. Legions of his undead clashed with the holy power of the temple brethren yet again. The dreaded army of bone and blade lost yet again. In response to his loss, the lich began work on a new breed: undead imbued with life—true life. The obitu were to be a life force as docile and obedient as his other minions with one marked difference; they were technically living, breathing entities.

Created by infecting undead with an arcane disease, the numbers of obitu grew quickly to the thousands. As they marched towards the distant citadel, something else began to grow as well; their free will. By the time the temple bastion was in sight, many obitu already began to doubt the wisdom of serving an evil master. The obitu rapidly converted to the goodly faith and became a bane to undead ever since. So wrap your boney fingers around that broadsword, march to the clatter of skeletal feet, and pull back that hood to reveal your undying smile. This new PC race will warm you to the bone!
Published under the Fourth Edition GSL. Full racial statistics for a new PC race, feats, monster blocks, and much much more! Colorfully illustrated.

62094.name: Entobian
62094.description:
From the publisher:

Intelligent insects-- we know of their hive like minds, alien dispositions, and callous attitudes. We have seen the mantis warriors, the bee people, and the ant-men. These are popular races, and those looking for something different are often drawn to them. Unfortunately, their hive society and tendency to be anti-human often makes these bug-men a poor match for many campaigns. Enter the entobian: These tenacious caterpillar people thrive in human societies. They hunger for adventure, individuality, and diversity. Driven by many of the same desires as other adventurers, they freely and willingly relate well with other races. They also have all the great aspects that make insects so interesting; 6 appendages, the ability to spin silk, and a truly different physiology than the other PC races. As an added bonus, at paragon levels they have the option to metamorphosis into a completely different insect; gaining not only a new form, but new powers and abilities as well. Imagine playing an axe wielding grub guy, an assassin beetle person, or even a spell slinging moth-man. Well, now you can, with the Entobian PC race brought to you by Alluria Publishing!

62095.name: Muse
62095.description:
From the publisher:

Ever wonder what inspires the authors of Alluria? Well perhaps it’s the enigmatic muse! In this new remarkable race, we explore a munificent denizen the demiplane of dreams who can inspire any adventuring party to new levels of power. Fleeing terrible nightmares planted by Hell itself, the muses escaped certain death by invading our world! A vision come to life, these beautiful and creative creatures continue to inspire greatness in all who strive to serve the gods. The muse is a truly selfless soul whose power is meaningless alone. No group will want to be without a muse to help them succeed, will you fill the need?

62096.name: Xax
62096.description:
From the publisher:

What happens when you cross the lawlessness of the Elemental Chaos with the madness of the Far Realm? You get the philosophical xax! The new xax 4E PC race introduces a random and alien element to the game, without diminishing power. Standing under 4 feet tall, these very odd looking creatures appear more like hideous monster than friendly ally. However, they are truly benevolent and intellectual beings that preach tolerance, acceptance, and the oneness of the universe. Still, it would be wise not to cross these great thinkers, as the blood of anarchy and insanity still runs hot in their veins. One never knows quite what to expect from a xax; one moment they are breathing fire, the next they may vanish entirely! Even the xax may be surprised. Add a little unpredictability to you game.

62097.name: Squole
62097.description:
From the publisher:

You always have room for jell-O? Well, whether or not this is true, it is our hope that you have room for the remarkable squole race in your game. Expanding on the arcane formula that created the gelatinous cube, a species of benevolent slime created human-shaped ambassadors to help prove to the multiverse that not all slime is awful, not all jellies are ochre, and ooze doesn’t have to be a four-letter word…well not a bad one in any case. Not quite human, these mannequin-like slimes take on adventurous tasks to prove their worth, discover the secret to humanity, and generally add a lot of flavor to any campaign. Tailored especially for the 4th edition game, the squole represent the only adventuring ooze that isn’t just a dungeon denizen.

62098.name: Numistian
62098.description:
From the publisher:

Hailing from the largest shopping mall in the multiverse are the numistians; a merchant race that specializes in making money. Originating from the mysterious demiplane of commerce, these humanoids can vary their height, eat and bleed coins, and have a great eye for lucrative endeavors. As the economy of the planes takes a dive due to a plague of cataclysms, this industrious race must now venture into your world to make a living. To a numistian, money is life! So gather your delectable copper pieces together and discover something new. Included is all you need to know about this fascinating new 4th edition PC race, including racial statistics, feats, and full details of the demiplane of commerce. Beautifully illustrated by Eugene Jaworski.

62099.name: Kval
62099.description:
From the publisher:

What is about a foot tall, has horns, a tail, and has hands as big as a man’s? …The kval, and they are about to invade your game in droves. When the balance of power suddenly tips towards evil, the world itself expels those responsible and the surrounding land it into a prison-like demiplane. In this isolated pocket dimension, the kval appear and begin to slowly multiply, destroying and consuming the fiends and eventually purging the infested land. Then, when the process is complete, the kval are deposited back into world in great numbers; thus maintaining balance. Kval, however, don’t stop there. They quest to find and defeat evil wherever it may be. Introducing the first working Tiny-size 4E pc race, the kval are certain to raise notice.

62100.name: Boggle
62100.description:
From the publisher:

We all know the legends of the brownie tinkerers. Many of us has seen a movie or read a book or two of goblins, gnomes, or other little people gifted with the ability to craft wondrous objects and strange mechanical devices. The boggles are the embodiment of that concept. Even they are the product of arcane tinkering; derived from lowly and dim goblin slaves. Boggles are born with an instinctual knack for building, breaking, and fixing things. They thrive on solving puzzles, crafting new solutions, and unraveling mechanical mysteries. Unfortunately, they are also born with a dreadful affliction that threatens their tightly wound intellect. In their old age, without a near constant infusion of a special alchemical formula, they degenerate into murderous maniacs. Ready to live life on the edge of genius and madness? Want to build a better orc-trap? Like breaking things? Then perhaps the Boggle PC race is meant for you!

62101.name: Critical Augmentation Feats
62101.description:
From the publisher:

A critical hit can be a devastating display of force that lets you take victory with a single well placed strike. However, sometimes, a critical hit can be underwhelming, doing nothing but dealing less than double damage. Feats such as Surprise Knockdown, Lightning Arc, and Triumphant Attack go some way to solving this problem, by granting additional effects when you score a critical hit. The critical augmentation feats presented here use those feats as precedent to give a wide variety for ways to make your critical hits more impressive.

The 34 feats presented in this product are spread across heroic, paragon and epic tiers.

62102.name: Horthnog and the Crimson Daggers
62102.description:
From the publisher:

Horthnog and the Crimson Daggers are a hardened goblinoid mercenary company. Suitable for interaction with a party of levels 7 - 13, they add some character to the Hobgoblin people; no longer will they be nameless faces who exist only to be slaughtered by adventurers. The company can be included in a campaign in many ways: they could be hired by the campaign's existing villain, be an ally of the party in the fight against said villain, or they could even overthrow the villain and Horthnog take his place. They could be the base of an entirely new campaign, or just used in a random encounter to add some detail. Horthnog himself is perfect to use as an end boss in a heroic tier game, or as an introduction to paragon.

This product contains everything you need to include the mercenary company into your games: descriptions, background, 2 adventure ideas and 15 encounter ideas using the mercenaries, including details on how to run a mass combat with the entire company. It includes 8 stat blocks for the different roles in the company, including the innovative standard bearer goblin minion lurker (leader), along with combat tactics. Finally, it includes a new skill challenge: finding a battle ground, and 9 pages of maps suitable for use with the Crimson Daggers as well as for many other combats!

Scrap that boring random encounter, and let your players meet Horthnog and the Crimson Daggers!

62103.description:
Pinky Li - The Bad Mushroom is book 1 in the Pinky Li Series.

It's a "Game 'n a book" you could say.

This book contains all of the following and is aimed at getting small children (4 to 7 years old) to read and play games at the same time!

- "The Great Mushroom Race game"
- An illustrated storybook about the Bad Mushroom.
- A Pinky Li Poster
- A Pinky Li Games and Coloring Book
- A book like box that can be turned into a 3D theatre

This Game in a Book is already available in English and French from the http://www.pinky-li.com website.
62103.name: Pinky Li: The Bad Mushroom

62104.name: Mythweaver: Reckoning (3rd Edition)
62104.description:
From the publisher:

Now available as a 128-page digest edition, Mythweaver: Reckoning is the game you HAVE to try! This expanded edition includes a complete campaign backdrop, new races, magic talents, skills and monsters.

So, what makes Mythweaver: Reckoning different from other fantasy RPGs?


A single mechanic allows you to do everything in the game- heroes, monsters, magic and items all follow the same rules, and all work in the same way.
The setting and system are fully integrated. Why do dwarves use storm magic? There's a mechanical and story-based reason. Why do gnomes and goblins dislike each other? There's a mechanical and story-based reason. Why are the heroes special? There's a mechanical and story-based reason.
This is the only book you need. Everything is here for ongoing play.
You can learn the rules in an hour, have a character made in fifteen minutes, and be bashing skeletal wardens upside the head with your mace before the evening is through.
You have the best support available for an indie fantasy RPG, including a small but vocal player community, ongoing support through a monthly magazine, and a growing web presence that rivals some full-time game companies.
It's got a responsive and dedicated creator. If you think something should be part of the game or if you don't understand why a mechanic works like it does, you'll probably get the content, fix, answer or explanation quickly.
You have the opportunity to become an integral part of the game's growth. Since Mythweaver is a small game with a small community, you can become an important part of the game's development. Also, since the core system is built around the concept of thousands of different lands each operating under unique circumstances, your home campaign logically fits into the Mythweaver cosmos, probably with minimal fiddling.
You have access to a back catalog of existing material that can quickly be integrated into this new game system, giving you resources that most other indie games cannot offer.

62105.name: Orgy
62105.description:
From the publishers ad:

Here's the exciting new indoor sport for people who love people. Orgy begins by choosing up sides (delightful custom) and centers around the "Porron" (translation: to pour it on) filled with your favorite libation. Object of the game is to see which team achieves the longest trajectory for the longest time with the fewest spills. Rewards to winners are optimal.

The game of Orgy comes complete with the beautiful, hand-blown Porron, bibs, buttons, "in-session" plaque and instruction scroll suitable for framing. Make your next party a bacchanalian smash with Orgy... just $10.

62106.description:
Players take turns placing tiles showing knotwork segments within a 5x5 grid. They may place either a tile of their colour or a neutral (white) tile each turn.

A player wins by having the highest score at the end of the game, given by the number of their tiles visited by a single knot.
62106.name: Celtic!

62107.name: The Lure of Delusion
62107.description:
From the website:

"This adventure was playtested in TLG’s weekly C&C game and was written for the Castles & Crusades tournament adventure being run by John Wright and Eric Piper at GenCon 2009."

From the back cover:

This module is designed for 6-8 characters with a challenge level of 2-4. Overland.

"Upon the edge of the world, beneath the eves of the Darkenfold forest, lie the Elkhorn Deeps. Here, where men eek out a living in the shadows of the forest, lays the small berg of Lead Hill. With stone walls and stout towers Lead Hill is a sanctuary or sorts, where travelers may lower their guard and relax. For beyond those walls are the wilds, and the Darkenfold is an unkind place, peopled by dark forces, fey, eldritch powers, and creatures long dead whose still wander the earth.

Of all the dangers the people of Lead Hill face, the most horrifying came to pass. Two children, too young to know the world, vanished from their home, carried off into the forest by some foul minded creatures. Faeries love to torment the lives of men through their suffering children, so few are surprised. Though none know who did it, why, or how. They left only tell tale signs behind.

Of late a hag haunted the area, pestering Lead Hill’s mage and its citizens, but they drove her into the forests. Harpies dwell in the woods not far and some have encountered the tree folk in the deeps. Other creatures abound and stalk the edge of wild, hunting for human prey. So none can say what has happened to the children, though all want them returned, or at the very least, those who lifted them, cast down and slain.

Enter the Elkhorn Deeps and attempt a rescue of the missing children! But be wary for things are not always as they seem and where allies and enemies work in tandem, great dangers often dwell. But above all, beware the lure of delusions."

62108.name: Traveller Chronicle (Issue 2 - Oct/Nov/Dec 1993)
rpgissuearticle: But I Wanted MY Character to Have…
How to Annoy an Aslan in TWO Easy Steps
62108.description:
From the contents page:

A Magazine Devoted to Traveller in all of Its Forms

The Traveller Chronicle is published quarterly by Sword of the Knight Publications.

Cover artist: Paul Sanders

62109.name: Der Unersättliche
rpgissuearticle: Diener des Lebens rettet Ilsurs Heilige Quellen
62109.description:
(user summary)
This adventure centers around the black wizard Xeraan, who reigns a demonic land. With the help of the heroes and the gods, his downfall may be possible.

62110.name: Snip Snap Snorem
62110.description: Very simple card game for children. It is played with a standard deck of cards without the jokers. The pack is dealt, and the first players selects and puts down a card from his/her deck. Each player in his turn then tries to match the card played just before his. The next player who can put down a card that matches the number card or face card says "snip", the third says "snap, the last says "snorum" and he can start the new round. The first player who gets rid of all his cards is the winner.

62111.name: Taxi Fly
62111.description:
Become the pilot of a flight from Paris to New York

Follow the instructions from air traffic controllers. Embark your passengers in various international airports and drive them as quickly as possible in New York.
You will be strategic (choosing the route, altitude, etc..)
With issues related to aviation, you expand your knowledge in aviation.

---

Devenez pilote le temps d'un vol Paris - New York

Suivez les instructions des contrôleurs aériens. Embarquez vos passagers dans divers aéroports internationaux et conduisez-les le plus rapidement possible à New York.
Il vous faudra faire preuve de stratégie (choix du parcours, altitude, etc.)
Grâce à des questions se rapportant à l'aviation, vous développez vos connaissances en aéronautique.

62112.name: Rune (Issue 14 - Summer 2001)
62112.description:
User Summary:

This issue includes information on the Gathering 2001.

Rules updates:

The definition and properties of alien life patterns.
Basic rules for use of ritual circles.
Playing off world characters.
Clarification of searching and theft of items.
Clarification of the damage system and related calls.
Branding as a punishment to be administered by the Militia.
New battle scoring system.

62114.name: Rune (Issue 13 - Spring 2001)
62114.description:
User Summary:

This issue includes information on the Heartland Games 2001.

Rules updates:

Each faction to have a dedicated plot team member.
Introducing the apprentice system for training from guilds and factions.
Summary of Occupational Skills for Archers.

62115.name: Poisoncraft: The Dark Art
rpghonor: 2004 ENnie for Best Electronic Book - Runners Up
2004 ENnie for Best Rules Supplement - Runners Up
62115.description:
From the Publisher:

Blue Deception - Quod - Wisp of Pallstone. These are but three of the lethal poisons that grace the pages of this book. Never again will your characters yawn at the mention of a poisoned arrow or the sight of a venomous serpent. For instead of merely being weakened by the kiss of poison, they may find themselves deafened, unable to cast spells, or thrown into the very depths of fear!

The first in our Complete line of d20 sourcebooks, this 96-page tome contains so much more than a simple recitation of poisons. A free-form poison creation system means the product of your character's skill will be limited only by the breadth of your imagination. The Complete treatment includes:

Detailed rules for brewing magical poisons, harvesting raw materials from vanquished foes, and creating antidotes.
More than 40 new feats, including metapoison feats, epic feats, and the dreaded Toxic Substitution.
Over 30 poison-related spells, including the ultimate in retributive magic: Vengeance on Tainted Hands.
An armory-full of new equipment and magic items, like the sinister Hollow-Blade and the legendary Staff of Serpents.
Six new prestige classes, including the Ki Corrupted and Toxomancer.
A menagerie's worth of baneful creatures, featuring the venomous gaze of the Syrallax and the grim essence of the Toxic Deathlord.
Adventure seeds incorporating all of the new rules for levels 1-20, including fully statted NPCs.
Detailed notes for using the Poisoncraft rules in any Monte Cook's Arcana Unearthed campaign.




You might find all of that in a regular sourcebook. In a Complete sourcebook, that's just the beginning! Blue Devil Games also gives you: rules on poison decay, the perils of handling poison, two versions of the poison cleric domain, three creature templates, a random poison naming table, a detailed description of all nineteen poison families, a character sheet addendum, and a Poisoncraft worksheet for creating new poisons. Oh, and did we mention the Codex Venenorum, with more than 60 poisons!

All this, brought to life by the incomparable artistic talents of Tyler Walpole, Kev Crossley, Jennifer Rodgers, and Fil Kearney.

62116.name: Franklyn's Almanack (Issue 1 - Winter 2005)
rpgissuearticle: Best Intentions - A Tale of the Republic of Sophia
Elite Soldiers of the Northern Crown
62116.description:
From the Publisher:

Welcome to Northern Crown, a colonial New World where the legends of North America come alive. Northern Crown is a place of high adventure, magic, and monsters, where history and myth intertwine.

Northern Crown is a campaign world set in North America's legendary past, in an age of frontier adventure, political intrigue, and supernatural horror. Inspired by history and infused with myth, it is a place where heroes fight for freedom, chart a vast wilderness, and battle unknown evils.

Adamant Entertainment continues its support of Northern Crown by Atlas Games with this first issue of Franklyn's Almanack, a supplemental quarterly featuring articles and adventures.

In this issue:

* Elite Troops of Northern Crown: A collection of prestige classes and sample characters representing the best soldiers in the world of Northern Crown: the Sophian winged saber, the Carolingian hippogriff lancer, and the Fran?ais gendarme.

* Best Intentions: A Tale of the Republic of Sophia: A full-length adventure for 1st - 3rd level characters, featuring a rogue automaton threatening the good people of Richmond!

62117.name: Starship Deckplans
62117.description:
From the back of the book:

A collection of deckplan maps for use with the Noble Armada miniatures game or the Fading Suns roleplaying game - it has also been approved for use with Traveller®! In fact, it can be used with just about any science fiction game. Five starships are featured, each depicted on 25mm scale maps - perfect for detailed boarding actions or roleplaying game firefights from corridor to corridor, stateroom to engine room.

Includes:

- Merchant League Sentry class escort (17" x 22" map)

- Decados Mantis class frigate (two 17" x 22" maps)

- Hawkwood Hornet class frigate (two 17" x 22" maps)

- al-Malik Odyssey class explorer (17" x 22" map)

- Luxury Liner (four 17" x 22" maps + Noble Armada Ship Display sheet)

62118.name: Franklyn's Almanack (Issue 2 - Summer 2006)
rpgissuearticle: Notorious Villeins and Sinister Cults: Le Dragon Rouge
62118.description:
From the Publisher:

Welcome to Northern Crown, a colonial New World where the legends of North America come alive. Northern Crown is a place of high adventure, magic, and monsters, where history and myth intertwine.

Northern Crown is a campaign world set in North America's legendary past, in an age of frontier adventure, political intrigue, and supernatural horror. Inspired by history and infused with myth, it is a place where heroes fight for freedom, chart a vast wilderness, and battle unknown evils.

Adamant Entertainment continues its support of Northern Crown by Atlas Games with the second issue of Franklyn's Almanack, a supplemental quarterly featuring articles and adventures.

In this issue:

* Notorious Villeins and Sinister Cults: Le Dragon Rouge: The first in a series exposing the hidden workings of some of the cults and secret societies introduced in Northern Crown: New World Adventures.

* The Onondaga Mission: A full-length adventure for 4th - 6th level characters, set deep in the territory of the Five Nations Confederacy, and involving several distinct plotlines which can be run as separate adventures.

62119.description: Roll and move that is set in a supermarket. The players walk between the shelves, trying to obtain goods for exactly 30 points and leave the supermarket first. There is no payment, instead players get the points for reaching the correct spaces on the board.
62119.name: Einkaufen im Supermarkt

62120.name: Einsteigen bitte!
62120.description: Game for the very young. Each player has a train consisting of an engine and a waggon. On his or her turn, a player spins a spinner which determines what happens with one or two cards that can be drawn. If not, they have to be given to other players. If a card matches the color on the player's waggon, it can be put into a slot on the waggon. The first player to place six passengers into his or her waggon is the winner. The game is Disney themed.

62121.name: Erzähl mir nichts
62121.description: The players tell stories. They also draw cards which contain words that have to be used. The other players have to guess which words were "artificially" added (i.e. demanded by cards). A charade variant is included.

62122.description: Players roll and move over a board. They can take up cards with certain pictures on the corresponding squares of the board. When a player meets another player, he or she can take a card from him/her (the loser goes back to the start). A cloud square means a card can be stolen from anyone. There are eight pairs of two cards each - when a player has both cards of a pair, these are protected from theft. The first player to collect 16 different cards is the winner.
62122.name: Ferien-Spiel

62123.name: Flott
62123.description: Players draw cards and lay down sets of 2-6 cards of the same color (at the end of the turn, there is a hand limit of 5 cards). The more cards are put down, the more points are scored (1-11). Most cards have only one color, some have two. The first player to reach 20 points is the winner.

62124.name: Häuschen dreh' dich
62124.description: The game contains 15 wooden houses which have different colors on both sides and a hole in the middle. A wooden marker is put into each hole. The first player gets the sixteenth marker and flips over a house, hoping that it matches the color of the marker. If so, the player keeps the house and the game continues with the marker that was in the house originally. If not, it's the next player's turn. The player with most houses at the end of the game is the winner.

62125.name: Blue Frog Tavern
rpgissuearticle: Schwerter und Dämonen: Piraten und Felsenfexe
62125.description:
From Back of Book:

At the end of the day you come upon a small country tavern near a dark forest; over the door is hung a wooden sign with a blue frog painted on it. You enter and ask the barman about the local gossip. He tells you that the local order of Red Robed Priests have been swarming over the countryside, questioning strangers. The accursed priests have been causing trouble, and their actions have hurt the tavern business. The barman also tells you that the new tavern owner is looking for a sword to hire.

Team up with Quartz the rock demon to recover the magic Blue Frog Amulet. The work is risky, the danger great - but the rewards are well worth the trouble!

(Just watch out for those red robed priests...)

62126.name: bOOLeO N-Edition
62126.description:
bOOleO N-Edition is a card game which combines strategy card play with the concepts of Boolean logic. Players must race to resolve an initial binary number to a single specific bit. This is accomplished through the use of logical gates.

Why is bOOleO N-Edition fun?
bOOleO N-Edition stretches your brain by using the fundamental concepts of Boolean algebra, specifically teaching you the concepts of Boolean operators/logic gates. Using the four different types of gate: NAND, NOR, NXOR, and NOT; you strategically build your logic pyramid, carefully watching the movements of your opponent, anticipating how your next move could destroy their pyramid. The pace can be lightening fast, the tension can blow your mind.

Integrates with:

bOOLeO

62128.name: Loded (Issue 1 - Spring 2008)
rpgissuearticle: Exotic Red Gold... The Evil Ore?
False Fancies: Fae Gold & Iron Pyrite
Gold Addiction: When Hoarding Goes Bad!
62128.description:
User Summary: the first issue of Loded was produced for the Moots 1108 and included the following articles...


Editorial by Zorkmid Flathead (Lorraine McKee).
Gold Addiction: When Hoarding Goes Bad! by Sionnach Argead (Gary Blake). On how to identify whether an individual is a Gold Addicted Dwarf and how to treat them accordingly.
Exotic Red Gold... The Evil Ore? by Pinta Lar'ga Top. On the horribly addictive Red Gold ore and how Kender may be unaffected by its curse.
False Fancies: Fae Gold & Iron Pyrite by Igneous Stonescribe (hairydave). On the freakish behaviour of those fools that lust after false perversions rather than real gold.
Centrefold: Cymrijan Gold. A double page spread of gorgeous gold straight from mine no.5 of the Borthawr Hold.
Forced Re-numeration: A guide on taking back what's yours, or taking what should be yours in the first place by Han Mc'Arlot, Debt Collector (hairydave).
Reader's Hoards showcasing woodcuts of the gold reserves that Loded readers have accumulated.
Dear Aunt Bridget... An advice column from a trained dwarven miner with over 140 years experience in mining, gold, gold mining, and to a lesser extent, life.
On the Brighter Side... A collection of jokes sent in by Loded readers.
Classified advertisements for a wide variety of goods and services.


Each issue was hand-coloured with gold marker and bound with gold thread.

62129.name: Op en neer
62129.description:
Op en neer (Up and down) is a childrens game. The purpose in the game is to try and finish the shopping tour in the department store as the first one.

In order to achieve this you need your player to get in and out of the elevator at the right floors for you to pick up the items on your shopping list. The elevator moves up or down depending on the spinning of an arrow. The player who spun the arrow may decide which number of floors the elevator will move (always to possibillities) and in which direction (up or down). On the gameboard are two elevators, connected by a small rope and when one elevator goes up, the other one will go down, and vice versa.

62130.name: Mythic Heroes
62130.description:
From the Publisher:

Mythic Heroes is the high-adventure solution for low-magic campaigns, written by the ENnie Award winning author of GRIM TALES.

Using the archetypes of myth and legend envisioned by Jung and Joseph Campbell, you can bring an epic sense of adventure to your campaign.

This product will show you how to:

1) Use action points to replace magic items in your campaign, without sacrificing heroic action;

2) Create exciting, high-level skill and combat challenges;

3) Use the archetypes of the Hero's Journey to bring a sense of cohesion and cooperation to the party, further enabling them to overcome the challenges of a mythic campaign.

62131.name: Hela's House of Dark Delights
62131.description:
A Tunnels and Trolls Mini-Solo Adventure.

From Back of Book:

Within Hela's House of Dark Delights you will find any pleasure or pain you desire, you need only ask for it...


this was originally printed in Different Worlds (Issue 22 - Jul 1982)

62133.name: Conquest, the card game
62133.description:
Conquest is an exciting game where the goal is to triumph over your opponents to gain the most land. A player may use a variety of characters, each with an unique ability, to travel to new lands, form alliances, and fight duels. This innovative card game uses each part of the card for different plays, even the backs!

In Conquest the card game, the object is to be the first player to capture the majority of landmarks. Players are dealt 5 cards. There are 9 landmarks in the game. Players can set the length and difficulty of the game at the start by choosing 3, 5, 7, or 9 landmarks or choosing landmarks that are more difficult to reach. Players move to different landmarks by playing cards from their hand that match the combination of terrain icons on each landmark card.

Each player assumes the role of one of 15 characters who may travel to different landmarks to try to take possession of them or duel opponent’s character. Players may also form alliances to avoid being attacked with the added bonus of getting the opportunity to secretly buy the allied player’s land. Some of the characters include samurai, pirate, spy, witch, and ninja. Each character has a unique ability that players can use to gain an advantage.

Players also control armies and officers that can battle to take over other player’s landmarks.

Conquest is not a CCG. It is a complete game with a deck of 63 cards, however, because each card can be used in multiple ways, it feels more like a deck of 200. Each corner on the face of the cards represents a different aspect of the game: characters, alliances, armies or terrain. On the back of each card is a mythological beast which is used to resolve duels between characters.

The game includes 63 cards representing:

15 characters (including 4 officers)
3 mythological beasts (dragon, unicorn, minotaur)
4 alliances (eagle, elephant, lion, bear)
4 terrain types (mountains, forest, desert, river)
12 shield markers
27 army cards
9 landmarks

62134.name: The Last Straw!: A Board Game on the Social Determinants of Health
62134.description:
From the publishers:

The Last Straw! is a fun and exciting teaching tool on the social determinants of health. The game has three objectives:

* to promote discussion about the social determinants of health;
* to help players build empathy with marginalized people and gain an awareness of players' own social location;
* to encourage learning in a fun and supportive environment.

In keeping with current research on the social determinants of health, socioeconomic status is a primary determinant of health in this game, as are race, gender, sexual orientation and other factors.

Feedback consistently demonstrates that players gain a better understanding of the social determinants of health and the interplay between forces at individual and community levels. Both players and facilitators ("Game Masters") report having a great time playing the game.

62136.name: Dragon (Issue 51 - Jul 1981)
rpgissuearticle: The Electric Eye: Computer Technology and Terminology
Leomund's Tiny Hut: Working your way up to first level
Plotting a Course For Choosy Players
62136.description:
Vol. VI No. 1 of Dragon Magazine.

Cover Art by Susan Collins.

This issue had a special Traveller section - "The Future is Here," as well as a complete boardgame from Tom Wham, "The SEARCH for the EMPEROR'S TREASURE."

62137.description:
From The Publishers Web Site:

Have you ever wanted to stop a Nazi Doomsday weapon hidden away in a lost Peruvian Valley amongst ancient ruins? Have you ever wanted to show those fools at the University the magnitude of your diabolical genius? In Where Heroes Dare! players field their own custom made Heroes and Villains along with their Companions and Lackeys in thrilling adventures set in the 1920s-1930’s Pulp Fiction and Movie Serial world. Players control as little as 3 models or as many as 30 depending on their style of play led by Characters with Shticks that give them flavor and ability such as Hard Boiled or Get a Load of Her! In these pages you will find rules covering Voodoo Zombies, Gadgets, Gear, Mad Science, Giant Robots, Vehicles, Airplanes, Artillery, Fierce Beasts, and a Campaign generator that gets you right in the action. The Perils and Fortunes tables add to the story by giving your Characters rewards or penalties from game to game as each Chapter unfolds. Where Heroes Dare! uses the Iron Ivan Games mechanics but adds in a new Dare! ability that allows Characters to solve mysteries, perform feats, and duke it out in Dire Duels. Where Heroes Dare! uses a point based system to create your teams and games are finish in about 2 hours. Are you ready for adventure? Then go Where Heroes Dare!
62137.name: Where Heroes Dare

62138.name: The Book of Wondrous Inventions
62138.description:
From the Back of the Book:

Have you ever wondered why, in a world full of magic, there are no enchanted labor-saving devices? Few magical modes of transportation? No bespelled byproducts of the inventor's art? Wonder no more! They are all here, in this latest compendium from the Game Wizard's lair: The Book of Wondrous Inventions!

The Book of Wondrous Inventions is useable with both the D&D and the AD&D game systems. Each invention is clearly outlined, including function, form, and hazards of use. Statistics and spell details are presented in a manner compatible with both game systems. Adventure scenario suggestions are given, as well as design instructions for characters who wish to build a duplicate device.

As an added bonus, a section is included which details a system for creating spells and magical items. This will prove especially useful to players and DMs who use the D&D game system; the detailed information is also of help to AD&D game players.

62139.name: (Su) Monsters: The Headless Horseman
62139.description:
From the Publisher:

(Su) Monsters: The Headless Horseman takes you deep into the world of terror. Armed with a flaming pumpkin and razor sharp sword, this creature roams the land in search of heads!

Written by a industry veterans, this book delves into creating your own Headless Horseman, thank to the Headless Horseman Template!

That's not all! This book includes five Headless Horseman monsters for you to be able to plop down into any campaign.

This book is rounded out with evil magic items and beautiful illustrations!

Evil has nothing to fear.

This product comes with a landscape PDF for easy onscreen viewing (fully bookmarked), a portrait PDF for easy printing (also fully bookmarked), a Rich-Text-Document version for easy cut / copy / paste (because we KNOW what a pain in the ass it is to copy/paste from a pdf).

rpgissuearticle: Campaign Journal: Risen from the Ashes
The Barber, the Thief, and the Smith
